title: Boris Johnson's Brexit lifeline as Leo Varadkar agrees 'there is a pathway' to deal
text:

Boris Johnson was today thrown a Brexit lifeline by Ireland's Taoiseach Leo Varadkar after both sides agreed that a deal is still possible in a cautiously worded statement.

The pair met for after talks between the UK and EU hit a low earlier this week - with Downing street briefing a deal was "impossible".

But embattled Mr Johnson was secured a joint statement that said, while barriers existed, a "pathway to a deal" existed - even if it gave no indication of how far from the path both parties currently are.

Mr Varadkar and Mr Johnson discussed Britain's future customs arrangement in the meeting at Thornton Manor on the Wirral.

In a joint statement Mr Johnson and the Taoiseach said there was a "pathway to a deal".

The statement said: The Prime Minister and Taoiseach have had a detailed and constructive discussion.

(Image: PA)

"Both continue to believe that a deal is in everybody’s interest.

"They agreed that they could see a pathway to a possible deal.

"Their discussion concentrated on the challenges of customs and consent. They also discussed the potential to strengthen bilateral relations, including on Northern Ireland.

"They agreed to reflect further on their discussions and that officials would continue to engage intensively on them.

"Following their discussions the Taoiseach will consult with the Taskforce 50 and the Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay will meet Michel Barnier tomorrow morning."

the two leaders were holed up in a luxury wedding hotel on the Wirral for “private talks”.

Mr Varadkar said on Twitter that he was “Looking forward to a detailed discussion to see if we can make any progress.”

(Image: PA)

But Mr Varadkar has said reaching a deal before next week’s Brussels summit would be “very difficult.”

The meeting - intended to take place away from the media spotlight - was being held at Thornton Manor, a grade II listed in rural Cheshire, which was the venue of Coleen Rooney’s 21st birthday party in 2007.

Meanwhile, Britain’s outgoing Chief Medical Officer has warned no-deal Brexit could still cause deaths due to medicine shortages, despite Government preparations.

Dame Sally Davies told the BBC: “The health service and everyone has worked very hard to prepare, but I say what I've said before.

"We cannot guarantee that there will not be shortages, not only of medicines but technology and gadgets and things. And there may be deaths.

"We can't guarantee there won’t.”

(Image: X06528)

And Former Chancellor Philip Hammond says Britain’s best hope was to pursue a zero-tariffs deal with the EU, keeping the UK inside the customs union and doing away with the need for a Northern Ireland backstop.

Such a deal would leave Britain unable to pursue free trade deals with other countries, but Hammond argued the image of a ‘buccaneering’ post-Brexit Britain was false.

“We all know these trade deals are of very limited potential value and likely to be very hard to negotiate without serious domestic and political consequences,” he told the Telegraph.
description: The joint statement said a deal was possible - but didn't say how close the parties were to agreement
